author: Evilknights

review:

There is nothing more annoying than being woken up in the middle of the night just to see "you have more swipes come use our subpar app." Stop being money hungry and give an option to turn off your terrible notifications trying to get me to use your app. If it's not a pretty girl talking to me, then I don't want tinder notifying me.

Edit: this has literally became one of the buggiest, worst apps I have ever seen. Continuously adding useless content, constantly logs you out and ask you to reconnect with Facebook then just says "account already given permission" doesn't load things, filled with insane amounts of spam accounts, and ask you leave a review literally every time you use it even if you already have. Don't download this, and definitely do not support the developers.

Edit 2: got banned for telling a girl "you are not in my dating bracket." I've had this for 5 years.

Edit 3: the number of swipes have been reduced dramatically. You only get about 10-15 right swipes now. Still a terrible app.

author: Louis R. Tursi
title: There‚Äôs no harm in giving it a try.
review:
To the general public, here is what I have to say. The experience one may have on an app like Tinder is subjective. It‚Äôs different for everybody and can highly depend on where you are located, your profile, your intent, etc. Males beware: do not be surprised when the majority of women you ask to hook up with you decline. Females beware: do not be surprised when the majority of men‚Äîor rather, boys‚Äîask you if you‚Äôre down to hook up. Whatever gender you are, whichever gender you are seeking, and whatever your intention with an app like this is, do not set your expectations high. Download it, swipe based on your interests, close the app, and go about the rest of your day and just see what happens. If it goes well, great! If it doesn‚Äôt, so what? Tinder is not the end-all-be-all, and that is my best advice.

Regarding the app itself though, as someone who has been using it on and off for a little over three years as of writing this, I‚Äôm surprised that it‚Äôs still as incredibly buggy as it is given that it was released over a decade ago. For example, the notification badges on it get stuck on a random high number for no reason, despite me having opened all of my matches and reading all my messages. As of late, the information within the app does not even update. In other words, I‚Äôll receive a new notification that I‚Äôve gotten a new match or that someone has sent me a new message, and upon opening the app, nothing has changed. I have tried signing out and signing back in, deleting the app completely (followed by waiting a while) and reinstalling it, and I‚Äôve even contacted support regarding all these issues and they were just about as helpful as my dog‚Äôs sh*t.

To conclude, I personally love what this app has brought and contributed to my life. I don‚Äôt know what my life would be like today without it, but I can guarantee it would not be the way it is now; far from it, in fact. I‚Äôve been using it for nearly three years and have had a blast with it since I first signed up for it. With all that being said, just try it already. It really couldn‚Äôt hurt; I honestly don‚Äôt know what you‚Äôre still waiting for. (Plus, you‚Äôve read this entire review for a reason, did you not?)

To the developers, all I have to say to you is... fix the functionality issues already. You update this app like once every two weeks claiming you‚Äôve "fixed bugs" (without any further explanation). Stop lying to make yourself look good, please and thank you.

author: Hillary$wank
title: The App continues to find ways to waste your time
review:
First off, I‚Äôd like to say that I‚Äôm coming at this review from the perspective of someone who thinks the app‚Äôs features have the potential to make the experience amazing (when working as intended). The main issue with the app is that there are too many annoying and repetitive bugs that completely destroy the user experience. 

First off, why even have an option to ‚Äúonly show people in this range‚Äù if every other profile you show is 2000+ miles away from the range I set? I mean, I get it. The app runs out of users to show you after a while and is forced to recommend profiles outside the range. But then why not just say that the app has run out of profiles and leave it at that? My guess is that the devs are trying way too hard to waste people‚Äôs time and keep them on the app as long as possible.

Second, literally every other swipe I get a notification that says ‚ÄúSuper like to increase your odds by 5x.‚Äù Now, I personally wouldn‚Äôt care about the constant notification. But it‚Äôs literally right above the profiles distance for you. Which is the number. one. consideration. when deciding on whether to swipe right or not. Again, this goes back to my initial theory that the devs are looking for ways to keep users on the app. 

I can‚Äôt tell you how many times I‚Äôve logging out and back in, deleted the app and it‚Äôs data. Nothing fixes these issues, because they‚Äôre not bugs, they‚Äôre features.

author: Wibbly Pibbles
title: Charging more, providing less
review:
I‚Äôve used this app off and on for years, and it has progressively gotten worse as far as what is provided for their users. 

Free users didn‚Äôt used to have limited likes, nor did it feel like they HAD to pay to have their profile seen. Now it seems like you have to pay to even be noticed. 

Paid users used to only have to pay $9.99/mo get a weekly boost, unlimited likes, a handful of super likes, and some good service.  Now, it‚Äôs one boost a month with a subscription, $8 per boost, 1 super like per month, and I can only imagine they‚Äôll continue taking more away.

I'm sick of spending money on a subscription just to find they took away yet another aspect of what made me enjoy having a paid membership. 

Please, just make this more accessible and friendly, rather than getting greedier by the day. I‚Äôm sure you make more than enough without gouging users for every little service.

author: Navyjax2
title: Too many fakes, scammers, ‚Äúcatfish‚Äù
review: Nothing is done to ensure that the people on the site are actually genuinely looking for a match. Captchas aren‚Äôt installed, having a ‚Äúverified‚Äù profile is optional, most members don‚Äôt fill anything in the bio because it‚Äôs not even required. Often you‚Äôll see people that are thousands of miles away by mileage, or people that are nearby, but their ‚Äúlive in‚Äù city is thousands of miles away because they‚Äôre just visiting your area. Needs to be a setting to only show those people that are physically nearby and also live nearby, or where you can select it if you want to see visitors. There‚Äôs no way to tell political leanings unless they put certain tags in their profile or put it in their bio. There‚Äôs no way to know important things like if they have pets or drink/smoke unless they happened to answer those questions-they‚Äôre optional. There‚Äôs no way to make it so you only see people that don‚Äôt have pets or don‚Äôt smoke or restrict out certain tags a person might add as their interest, for example ‚ÄúActivist‚Äù. To be a better app, these things need the focus, not the cutesy ‚ÄúVibes‚Äù questions that don‚Äôt have much meaning to whether they‚Äôre going to be a good partner or not. And having to ‚ÄúBoost‚Äù in order to be seen by people you like is lame - it ought to just automatically put them front and center for them and tell you if they rejected you or not. But anything for a buck, eh, Tinder?

Is overrun with scammers now. Most of the messages I get are from women that cannot properly write in English, and my settings are set to just 5 miles from Los Angeles, ha ha.

So, when I say local to LA, and it says they live in ‚ÄúCalifornia,‚Äú I know they are fake. When locals in Los Angeles put their location, they do not write California, ha ha. Anyway, I thought it might backfire, reporting so many people. And it did! I went to look around yesterday, thought I would try again, come to find out I have been banned from the site.  Never said anything inappropriate, just looking for a nice local girl. But I guess they don‚Äôt want regular local people on there. They must be making money from the scammers.  Tinder is a joke!!!

I was, and still am, insanely confused because there‚Äôs no way I could‚Äôve violated any terms and conditions or community guidelines since I hadn‚Äôt swiped or messaged anyone, I had barely begun to set up my profile. I emailed to see what had happened, but they sent back a generic response saying that they couldn‚Äôt give me any more details and there is no appeal process. I followed up and their customer service is unhelpful, slow to respond, and basically at this point I‚Äôm just giving up. There are enough options for dating sites that I‚Äôll gladly choose another one that values it‚Äôs users and takes issues seriously. If I could give zero stars I would. Really disappointing, especially since I‚Äôve had the app before and had a good experience.

title: Filled with bots. Not worth your time or money.
review:
My friends raved about how well this was to meet girls, so naturally, I wanted to try it myself being out of a relationship for about a year, time to move on.

Downloaded it, set up a profile; realized you can‚Äôt do much with a free version, so I tried the Gold for $25 (a bit steep), that has unlimited likes and you can see who likes you, among other things.

I‚Äôve had match after match, come to find out, all bots and scammers that try to get you to add them on Snapchat, and then they unlatch. For $25, you‚Äôd expect the company to crack down on phishers and scammers, for the service charge, I guess not.

I‚Äôve cancelled my subscription following, and probably will give up even the free version in a month when this is done, they won‚Äôt prorate and I might as well use up the remainder of what I‚Äôve paid for.

Do yourself a favor. Use bumble or hinge, or meet people the old fashioned way; bars, social clubs, etc. Don‚Äôt waste your hard-earned money on this trash. Learned my lesson.

author: Kekle Monster
title: Mediocrity of Matches
review: In the app, I find a wide variety of people to choose from. Spam bots, people who are visiting and only in town for a week, people looking for drugs, girls who‚Äôs accounts are inactive (saw one where she had a new bf in her insta pics), and of course the ones who I have no interest in swiping right to. I feel like tinder needs a better system to get rid of these things or a more organized way to go about this. Find a way to get the most active accounts paired waiting to match along with those who have already swiped right on you so you can match faster. I mean, if this app is based off the success of people being able to find matches I feel like it should be simpler and easier to find those matches. In the terms of things i don‚Äôt want to see its people who think that this is for anything other than going out on dates or hooking up. There should also be a section for those who aren‚Äôt local. If they are not from my state or area and are ‚Äúin town for the week on vacation‚Äù there should be some kind of tab to access those people and a way to not have them show up in my feed. Putting out a warning or label saying that looking for gas plugs 420 friendly or weed etc should get your account banned/suspended. All in all, it‚Äôs a good app. I like it, just wish it didn‚Äôt take me thousands of swipes to finally find a match without paying to see who‚Äôs swiped on me. Have to be re verified every time I change my location and it‚Äôs annoying. Pls fix soon Sincerely, A dude who‚Äôs lonely

I asked for for a specific reason because I know they can‚Äôt come up with one. Eventually they blocked me from emailing them (won‚Äôt send anymore) and now I don‚Äôt know how I can contact them for my refund‚Ä¶ since they kept billing me for my subscription! author: Loren KLD
title: Admitted to banning my by accident - now blocked forever
review:
I‚Äôm like the thousands of others who left a one star review about being banned for no reason at all. 

My account was banned. I have the most vanilla account on the planet and was certain it was an error. Tinder responded and admitted it was their error and that my account was banned (forever) because it was accidentally flagged as a spam account.

Then they proceed to tell me to sign up again, but that‚Äôs impossible because you have to use your phone number to sign up (you can‚Äôt use a burn number) and my phone number is forever banned. 

So thanks Tinder for having the worst algorithm on the planet that bans real accounts FOREVER with no way for those people to ever get back on the app.

You have an obligation to have a more sensitive and compassionate process around this. You know many of the people on your app are already feeling rejected, lonely, and depressed, and you make it worse by banning them from a way to connect with others and accusing them of doing something they didn‚Äôt do. It‚Äôs so wrong on so many levels. 

I mean does anyone on your team actually read these reviews?! You would think you would change the process of banning accounts by now given the thousands of complaints that say they all experienced the exact same thing.

author: Sfubbkocn
title: Not good anymore
review: I've used tinder on and off for nearly eight years now and the quality of the app and interactions has gone off of a cliff. I've had Platinum for more than six months now and still hardly get any matches, even when using boosts, even during swipe surge, even when using boosts during swipe surge. Sometimes my profile will be shown at random times and I'll get 10 like within half an hour, but this doesn't happen too often and I'll only get a couple a day. The culture has also changed around it for the worse, many years ago it was super easy to have a bunch of matches that led to conversations that led to dates. Now almost none of the matches reply to my messages, and the ones that end up planning a date often cancel or don't show up to the date. I'm quite tired of feeling burnt out by this app and really don't see much of a future with it for myself or perhaps with other men that may be having the same experiences. It certainly isn't as good as it was in the 2013- 2017 era. In conclusion the best two words I could use to describe this app are depressing and overpriced.

author: men in a new world
title: Tinder is it good or is it bad.
review: It‚Äôs not necessarily tinders fault . But the app has become more of a tool for hook ups vs relationships . Which is okay I guess but I‚Äôm not really looking for a hook up . It‚Äôs not tinders fault but I‚Äôm not deeply satisfied with what I‚Äôm getting through the app . It‚Äôs not the app it‚Äôs self it‚Äôs the people that use the app . I‚Äôm not perfect by any means. I‚Äôm just on the lower end of the stick as are a lot of dudes . Tinder isn‚Äôt bad and it‚Äôs not amazing either. It‚Äôs right in the middle I guess you just need to be lucky . But I don‚Äôt pay for the membership either . Which I think is why some people have success vs others . In my opinion love shouldn‚Äôt be bought . But that‚Äôs just an opinion and how can you love someone without actually having a physical interaction with them over a period of time . Which is the purpose of the app . It‚Äôs not tinders fault although the membership is expensive and restrictive towards the guy looking to be in relationship vs the guy that‚Äôs looking to explore multiple options. It boils down too American culture. Tinder is in the middle you can‚Äôt monitor how a person will be in person or how they will react later on .  3 stars is a good gauge if the app was less restrictive towards people who haven‚Äôt paid for the membership I would give them more stars .The average person won‚Äôt want to pay for the membership but again nothing is free . But again love shouldn‚Äôt be marketed . It also became business too many options and a lot of marketing towards curiosity .

author: Natasha_Kimberly

review: The first thing I loved about Hinge is that you can really be yourself and express that without going into a full length about me bio. Funny thing, I came across this guys profile and I really liked him. The little things he put on his profile made me laugh and I wanted to know him better plus he is extremely good looking, I didn‚Äôt swipe cause I just assumed this guy would ignore me like most. Two days later I had a message from him! Yes, the same guy I was really interested in! I couldn‚Äôt believe it, I made a funny reply to something on his profile and I remember him saying that that was the best response anyone could have ever given and from there on we started talking nonstop, fast forward three months later and we are dating and very, very happy. I can‚Äôt believe I found him on a dating app and where we are now, if you told me that this would happen I wouldn‚Äôt believe you. But hey Hinge just proofed that this dating app is awesome and works. I definitely recommend giving Hinge a try!

author: **TaY**=o)
title: Male Users Leave Hinge In Droves As Algorithm Flops
review:
Hinge, at one point, was the ‚Äòdiamond in the rough‚Äô dating app amongst a flurry of competitors. Its user interface encouraged a dialogue both in the forms of prompts and easy-to-engage photography seen on profiles.

For every 10 potential matches for men, maybe 4 or 5 would be of interest.

So what happened?

Like most apps nowadays, Hinge got to work on ‚Äúimproving‚Äù its algorithm(s). The aim, obvious as it may seem, was to produce BETTER user experiences by matching users with seemingly similar traits, interests, and (purely subjective) ‚Äúlevels of attractiveness‚Äù.

And now, for every 10 potential matches for men - *maybe* 1 is of interest (the experience reported by multiple male users).

What it did not take into consideration is the demographic breakdown of its users: roughly 65% are men while the remaining 35% are female (according to Hinge itself).

This disparity is also heightened by basic gender preferences, primarily the 80/20 principle, in that 20% of the men receive 80% of the attention of women (think of high school and how all of the girls wanted to date the boys on the football team).

In summary, the apps algorithm(s) have made matching a one-way street in which the women get plenty of potential matches with people of similar or higher attractiveness, whereas men do not.

So if you‚Äôre a female searching for a male - you‚Äôll have no problem.

If you‚Äôre a male searching for a female - you‚Äôd have better odds of meeting a woman at an all-male prep academy.

review:
I like the format of the app, it isn‚Äôt bad and mostly beginner friendly. However, I was recently just banned for no reason. I was casually talking to just one person and a few days later the developers banned me saying I broke their terms and services. I submitted an appeal asking for what I did wrong and within 7 minutes they responded saying they can‚Äôt disclose any information but all they can assure is after reviewing my account again I somehow did something wrong and my account is staying banned. I highly doubt they ‚Äòcarefully‚Äô reevaluated my profile within those 7 minutes while responding with a paragraph response. I have other apps, used this one before a handful of times and never once had an issue. It‚Äôs rather disrespectful when you spend some money to support the app and they completely disregard your appeal without even telling you the reason why it was banned. I‚Äôve seen many women who have had profanity and other things on their profiles and have no punishment done but given how I‚Äôm one of many guys who use the app I‚Äôm easily disposable.
Besides the unfairness of the developers a complaint I have is the distance settings. I have it set to where if there are no people left within the distance then no profiles should show up. However, rather following how other apps have it, they decide to show you profiles in other states and across the US. What are the chances I‚Äôm actually going to meet up or have a future with someone that far? 
If you want to download the app for yourself go ahead, just don‚Äôt waste your time taking the time to make it a serious profile since you could randomly get banned at any moment.

author: Mila nicole
title: Bots
review:
I‚Äôve been using the paid version of Hinge since this last summer. There are times when I don‚Äôt get on much, so some of this is on me, yet it hardly seems worth the money when I‚Äôve squeezed out three, in person dates. (One was with someone I already knew and ‚Äúbumped into‚Äù on the app). I used Bumble for a bit a couple years ago, and went on 3 dates within the first week. 
Two of my main complaints; first, they put all their most attractive members in the ‚ÄúStandouts‚Äù section. You can only contact Standouts by sending them a rose. (Yeah‚Ä¶it feels like The Bachelor) You get 1 rose/week for free, and beyond that, you have to pay for more. They‚Äôre not cheap. 
Second: BOTS! I‚Äôve seen a significant increase in the number of bots since I started using. And they‚Äôre usually in the Standouts. This morning I noticed at least 3-4 in the mix. They‚Äôre always extremely conventionally attractive, from another country, their personal info has something nonsensical in it, the prompts mention marriage or long term relationships, and pics feature them w/animals. If you connect w/ them, they immediately respond and after a few messages, ask for your phone number or try to get you on What‚Äôsapp. I always report them, but I can‚Äôt even imagine how many users are unwittingly spending money on roses for bots. Not cool.

The more information on your profile or another persons profile increases the chances of you liking something other than just their looks I found that this has led to much more engaging and relatable matches with others not only that but leading those comments on their profile has led to easier conversations as it is a total ice breaker The conversation starts with the comment that you made after you match and you can build off of what you sent I found this has led to more genuine conversations and has been a overall amazing experience Ive had tinder and bumble for several years now and I found the whole experience to be very difficult with few matches and disinterested people even when I use the paid subscriptions little changed After a few days of downloading this app I saw a completely different results for the reasons I mentioned above Theres so many features that allow a person to be able to follow up on people who like them without the use of a paid subscription Ive been able to match with several people and I am very interested to meet one of them Overall Ive been absolutely thankful for discovering this app Thank you Hinge and best of luck to the rest of youI dont know how they do it but it works I have never in my however many years of online/app dating, regardless of the site or platform, been able to meet someone I was compatible with. It‚Äôs difficult sorting through, what is essentially lists and lists of people (who sometimes distract you with their pretty faces and not much else), hoping that you find someone who is compatible with you. These new changes that aim to get you off the app, whatever they are, they work. After being on here for a couple/few months, Hinge more and more started to send me men I found attractive and was more likely to have good conversation with. I met a guy that I really like, and we‚Äôve been seeing each other for less than a couple months but I have never met a man who I could talk to for hours on end like this. We did the video calls and the questioning game through Hinge and eventually met up for a social distanced picnic.

author: BoBoTheMonorailClown
title: Designed to be deleted coz it‚Äôs trash
review:
Shows no one you want and all those you don‚Äôt. Is hinge a trash can for unattractive people? 

I‚Äôm guessing it‚Äôs in a drive to push you towards the paid version, but originally the app would show a mix of people, some I‚Äôd be interested in and some I wouldn‚Äôt. Now days all the app shows are people I‚Äôd rank 3/10 or less. It‚Äôs very clear that this isn‚Äôt ‚Äúby chance‚Äù or that it‚Äôs a balanced representation of the people around me, as the standouts feature ALWAYS has people that aren‚Äôt repulsive, but this now seems to be the only place on this app that you find them. 

Sorry honey, I don‚Äôt find a 5‚Äô5‚Äù girl weighing 230lbs attractive and I don‚Äôt think many do‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ I would prefer these aren‚Äôt the only girls that show up on my regular feed.  It‚Äôs as though by showing you all the undesirables, they think people are going to pay to unlock the less ugly people‚Ä¶.. really? If you are playing these tricks before I pay, what tricks do you play after I‚Äôve paid and I can‚Äôt get a refund. It seems as though they also stop most matches going through as I used to get a response to a good proportion of likes, but now I never get a reply. The same goes for receiving likes. I originally used to receive a few likes a week yet over the last many months don‚Äôt receive any. I find it hard to believe my unchanged profile would have suddenly dropped all its appeal.

Either the developers have accidentally ruined this app, or more likely, the executives intentionally ruined it by trying to force you into the paid version- ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs our next plan in the quest for MONEY? I know, let‚Äôs stop showing people that would actually match with each other and then bombard them with the option to upgrade so they have to give us $ in order to actually get use out of this app‚Äù.

One thing I do find interesting is that new users haven‚Äôt had time to be profiled by the hinge algorithm yet so hinge still shows them to everybody until it realizes they are attractive and stashes them away where they won‚Äôt show except for the expensive standouts section. 

Don‚Äôt download this app, or if you do, make the most of the first couple of weeks you have it. After that you may as well delete it because all you‚Äôre gonna find are uglies & fatsos or at least the opposite of the type of people you were originally trying to match with. (If fatsos are your thing it‚Äôll probably end up showing you all the hot girls instead)

author: Open Mouth Insert Foot

First woman to ask me of my number for such a 3rd party app, resolved in discovery that women are still selling their bodies for business. Sort of the F you to the old Uncle Sam of the US of A. So far, disappointed; society will never be revolutionized by what is in stores from technology, just a few more years.

author: Hotel_Matt
title: Something changed, a new algorithm? Don‚Äôt bother with this app anymore
review:
Something changed for the absolute worst. It seems as though hinge have implemented a new algorithm that pushes the least ‚Äúswiped right‚Äù users to the very front. This will sound vain, but in the past I used to get a mix of attractive and unattractive girls showing. The last month or so it has been purely unattractive girls, as in, the most unattractive that you without a doubt swipe left on immediately.  

I‚Äôm not gonna sugar coat it: 
This would make sense to improve statistics, as if all the regular/ hot girls are always getting matches and the uggos are not, the app won‚Äôt meet whatever goals the corporation have set for number of matches, therefore they push the uggos so they have the best chance of finding a match, and barely show the hotties seeing as they are likely to get many matches from just minimal exposure. 

I myself used to get many matches, albeit from uggos who probably match with any 5 or above. However in the last month or so I haven‚Äôt even been  getting these. It straight dropped off. This algorithm would also fit this situation as I was getting too many matches so I have been dropped to the ‚Äúshow least‚Äù or at-least ‚Äúshow less‚Äù pool. 

Don‚Äôt bother signing up for this app unless you have a ‚Äúthing‚Äù for what the majority of society deem ‚Äúunattractive‚Äù. The developers may have some politically/ socially responsible response and claim something else, but we all know the PR machine is strong with large corporations so take their reply with a grain (or many) of salt. 

Lets be honest, we‚Äôre not on here to find the sexiest people in the world, but no one wants to date someone they find physically repulsive. Don‚Äôt waste your time on this app anymore, it used to be good and a nice balance

author: noisy

It‚Äôs a little cart before the horse to earnestly seek a serious relationship vs doing what you love and letting the relationship grow out of that. But this is apping, not living. Also, let‚Äôs face it, I wouldn‚Äôt be on here were I not on some level interested in a (ptooey) serious relationship. 

So I guess give it a go? Just give it a few weeks without paying. The guys you pass over will either be back in your feed or, if they‚Äôre not, they weren‚Äôt worth it anyway. 

Lovingly, 
Dr. Ruth

author: Alfred Ricci

review:
I got recommendations about Hinge, much higher quality people. The single most glaring issue with this app is the absence of an ‚Äúabout me‚Äù section. You‚Äôre basically choosing to swipe left or right only on pictures and very limited text. Instead of an about me section where you can write in detail about who you are and the person you‚Äôre looking for, they have a voice message, you get to record your own voice. Completely in adequate for understanding who someone is and what they‚Äôre looking for. Yes, it‚Äôs cute to hear someone‚Äôs voice, but it is not a substitute for allowing someone to write in detail about themselves and their match.

NOT WORTH THE MONEY 

Hinge used to be great because it allowed us to actually build relationships with substance where bumble became a hook up app. In the past year, hinge has allowed the same scammers and catfishers to continually re-create accounts back to back to back so BEWARE. I‚Äôve reported nearly 100 to 200 fake scammer catfish accounts in just a few months providing details that Hinge should look for in order to permanently block this person or these persons from re-creating accounts every second that they get reported. 

Hinge can easily block the IP address or find another way but they refuse to do it. Instead after me reporting over 100 fake profile accounts that keep popping up with the same bio, instead of protecting us they came out with a new terms and conditions that is so long and it only protects them, not us. They know that by leaving these scammer catfish accounts with pictures of models up, they will surely attract more people that will pay for membership in order to speak to these catfish accounts.

author: Not Happy 00034
title: About 99% Scam/Fraudulent Matches
review:
I was on this app for about three weeks. Unlike any other dating app I‚Äôve ever used, literally almost every ‚Äúmatch‚Äù of mine was some scam artist. At first I thought maybe I was just being paranoid, but then I actually received an email directly from Hinge customer support (unsolicited by me) telling me that one of my matches was automatically removed because is was determined to be a fraudulent profile. So, that immediately confirmed everything that I‚Äôve been experiencing. 
Like many others have commented here, all these con artists do is try to get you to leave the app and go onto another like WhatsApp, etc in order to get your phone number or other personal information. How does Hinge let this happen to such an extent? They have no way to verify profiles? 
Needless to say, I deleted the app immediately.

review: The user interface is pretty good and is set up to make you read someone‚Äôs entire profile, which is helpful. Within a month I matched with a few nice men and went on great dates. However I think the app‚Äôs ‚Äúalgorithm‚Äù is misleading. I was under the impression it aligned you with people who have the same interests/mindsets, but in reality it just shows everyone who has a profile in general (at least where I live). You make the match if someone liked your profile and you liked there‚Äôs back, like other apps. Many men who liked my profile didn‚Äôt have the same interests (or even moral values) as me. I never tried dating apps before this one so I‚Äôm not sure how they generally function, but thought that hinge‚Äôs algorithm at least would make suggestions. Maybe the paid version does it, I only had the free version. All in all, it helped connect me with nice guys I‚Äôd consider as great friends, but not romantically. I‚Äôll be deleting the app, but to go back to the old-fashion way of meeting and dating.

Though I acknowledge some really mean that. Also a lot of girls just seem to be looking for Instagram followers. I stopped liking those who put their Instagram in the answers to their prompts. If they do answer you, they usually start off by saying how little they‚Äôre on this app and want you to follow them on Instagram. You could probably figure out where things go from there.

Still definitely possible to find someone here, just watch for the red flags. Good luck ladies and gents‚Ä¶

title: I found my future wife.

Yes, you will always have non genuine people looking for something strictly physical. Hinge on the other hand helped me filter out the fakes. The way the system is set up gives you a chance to like a quote, viewpoint, answer and of course pictures. You are forced to be more genuine and look past the initial hot or not instant swiping feature that other apps encourage. Hinge will always be the app that connected me with my best friend  and for that I‚Äôm forever grateful. The wedding is scheduled for September of 2022. Give Hinge a try. title: Discrimination
review: Hinge is a totally biased platform. I was banned and had my account and all contacts deleted for "violating their terms of service," when there was no violation, I double checked by reading through all their terms. Basically, anyone can report you for any motive they may have and just check the "they made me uncomfortable" box and Hinge will delete you. They give you the option to "appeal," which I did, but then give you some canned response that the decision is final, and refuse to specify the terms you violated or provide any more information when requested to. I've spoken with other women who this has happened to, and apparently it's pretty common with Hinge - there are even articles written about it. Get your act together Hinge.

His iTunes charged him for a non existing account and he‚Äôs reached out to Hinge and ITunes for an automated pay that shouldn‚Äôt be there. iTunes IT says he shouldn‚Äôt be getting charged for it but Hinge keeps resubscribing when he CHANGES his cards. author: Maribelle32
title: Don‚Äôt waste money on roses
review:
I‚Äôm not impressed with this app.  I found the attractiveness level pretty low for the men I saw and the matches sent to me were all no‚Äôs from me.  The ‚Äúalgorithm‚Äù is terrible (and I‚Äôm an attractive, educated woman).  I tried this app for a few months (both paid and free) bc I had heard it was the app to go on to find a relationship but the way the app works, I found very non conducive to maximizing matches. Notifying each time you send a ‚Äúlike‚Äù made me less likely to send one if I was on the fence. I have gone on so many actual dates on Tinder and Bumble. With Hinge, I went on zero and had much fewer matches.  The conversations I had were lackluster and sometimes w men who were hours away.  I paid for 3 months to see all the likes I received at the same time and thinking I‚Äôd want to have more than 8 likes per day but I barely could find one per day.  (It was more like one per week).

Don‚Äôt waste your money on buying extra roses.  The app makes you think you should buy them to match with the ‚Äústand outs‚Äù but those people get recycled and show up again and again. I‚Äôm not even sure they‚Äôre all real profiles.  It‚Äôs a great marketing ploy but seems a bit like a scam. There‚Äôs no way to know if the person received the rose, if you‚Äôre outside their preferences. Also, the person gets a notification that a rose was sent to them from you and that it‚Äôs extra special - so embarrassing (I only know this bc someone sent me one).  It won‚Äôt help you w getting more dates, believe me.  

Guess there‚Äôs an app for everyone but this is not the one for me. Hope others have better luck but learn from my mistake and don‚Äôt waste your time or money on extra roses bc of the ‚Äústand outs‚Äù list that you are sent.

author: Supercheif
title: Good overall, but ‚ÄúStandouts‚Äù is an awful feature
review:
At the basic level, the app is well built and functions well and I do really like to approach they take compared to other apps. However, the ‚ÄúStandouts‚Äù feature completely ruins the app my taking the most desirable women and putting them behind a paywall, essentially. You have to use a ‚Äúrose‚Äù, which is like a super-like, instead of a normal like for this curated list of potential matches. The fact that you have to pay for additional roses beyond the one you get from time to time isn‚Äôt even what bothers me, but it is the obligation to use a rose because it comes off as desperate and cheesy and I‚Äôve NEVER had a match from a rose or super-like. It completely sabotages your chance with a girl to send a rose, so it makes these girls completely off limits.

author: dontworrybhappy
title: Designed to Delete Immediately üëéüèºüëéüèºüëéüèº
review: I started using Hinge about 2 months ago and I had really good results matching with women. The fact that you need to engage with people by text messaging to match, instead of just swiping leads to more interesting connections. After a few weeks I had 15 matches and 5 dates set up. So far so good. Then I came across a profile with 5 lackluster photos and a 6th photo that made the person look like a model. Maybe it was catfishing, but I liked the photo and told the person it was a really great shot and they should put it up higher. The women responded with a tirade about how men don‚Äôt get to decide what‚Äôs a good photo or not, What the F**k, go to H**l, etc. I responded tongue and cheek and thought it was over. A day later I was banned. No warning, no temporary suspension, banned for life! It didn‚Äôt matter than 15 other women had matched with me. One woman flagged me, and I was gone without even an explanation. Cancel culture at its best! Hinge hides behind the claim it is protecting women but in reality it is disrespecting men. It didn‚Äôt even respect the women that had matched with me by giving them an explanation or a way to keep in touch. One woman that I had been texting with off the app, contacted me and asked why I unmatched with her. Hinge does some things right, but like many other hi-tech behemoths they think they own you, and they basically do. They can cancel you without notice or an explanation and you don‚Äôt even get access to the the data and connections you made. Before you get too invested in this app, take a look at the board of directors. A bunch or corporate suits that don‚Äôt look like they have been on a date since the 80s. Then do yourself a favor and delete the app before you waste your time. Who would have known that‚Äôs what they meant when they said the app was designed to be deleted.

author: Groupon?
title: Please read reviews before subscribing
review: While reluctantly, I'd say that this is my overall preference of the "apps" but it's been far less likable lately. The discover page has always been a mixed bag, some people aren't your type and some are, that's life. However, between standouts Ave the recent update, that no longer seems to be the case. The discover feed is filled with brand new accounts (which is fine, they've been the closest to the type of people I tend to match with) or accounts that are significantly different from any person I've ever matched with on the app. From incomplete profiles, to basic answer incompatibilities and an algorithm that clearly knows your preferences but ignores them behind a paywall. I purchased the premium model and I'm currently using it, I don't recommend. My best matches are in preferred, which is nice but I never see any of them in the feed and even with a premium account, you only get one way to match with you "preferred match" for free for a week. So, you'll see about 70 profiles that you really like in a week and you're only able to reach out to one, even with premium. It seems to me that the hinge algorithm has gotten better, as the preferred page has really good matches. However, that algorithm seems to go out the window for discover. For anyone who likes/liked this app, I'd recommend getting the free version. You'll save money and annoyance, you might even see more people that you like. It seems like I was served more people who are a good match before I paid, I'm assuming it's a way to make sure that free users see enough people that they like to think that it's worth it. It's not. You'll likely swipe through a sea of profiles are largely not what you're looking for only to be annoyed that you paid and still can't even send a basic like to your preferred matches. Save your money, use it for free and good luck finding love, or whatever else you're trying to find here

author: üåπNaked chatüëâssu8.comüåπlive c

After that, it‚Äôs up to chemistry and no app has that. I have made connection and I waited for the conversation to start and the clock ran out I have made connection and had second thoughts and let the clock run out I have also met some amazing people and built lasting relationships Bumble to me seems safe exudes quality with the look of the app the simplicity of use and the opportunity to add additional services for a price I have done that once but really isnt necessary It is also very easy to update your profile as you learn what seems to be working and maybe what isnt With patience you will connect Maybe not everyone you swiped right but likely the right ones Two tips be HONESTabout everything including your age and second use the extended clock strategically it can pay dividends Bumble isnt perfect but no dating app is Happy BumblingFirst off I can find my home town in the app I live and grew up in a Small town in Ohio and I can find it therefore I cannot complete my profile That means I cant get the 100 and it drives me nuts Also I dont understand why yall need to include our political views as an option on our pages This country is divide enough as is and having the fact that I am a republican on my page is only gonna drive people who don‚Äôt know me away, and I ain‚Äôt gonna lie and not say what I am. author: HamsterJuice
title: Arbitrary algorithm with overpriced premium "features"
review:
I've used this app two separate times a few years apart. The first time, finding matches was relatively easy and consistent and I met some really great people. I entered a relationship with one of them for a couple years and deleted the app.

A few months ago I redownloaded Bumble and Hinge. My experience with Bumble this time around has been pretty abysmal. The very first day there was an influx of likes, and in the weeks since I've received around 5 total. Compare this with Hinge, where likes are more direct than a simple right swipe, yet I receive them on a daily basis. I use the same photos on both apps; the only difference is the apps themselves.

That influx of likes you get your first day on Bumble seems very manipulative considering your profile will likely not receive that kind of attention ever again. They try to get you hooked with an initial burst of likes, and then they start pushing their absurdly priced premium features. It's embarrassingly transparent.

If you're serious about making quality connections, Bumble is unfortunately no longer the place to do it. Your time and energy are better spent elsewhere.

Heck, it‚Äôs how I coped from past trauma (having those standards). I will immediately be deleting this app. Thanks a lot.

title: Great App/Small Suggestion
review:
With the facial recognition software Bumble uses for your site, it would be a MILLION DOLLAR IDEA, to ensure the FIRST picture in someone‚Äôs profile is just ONE PERSON. 

Half the time you see more than one person in the first picture; it‚Äôs ‚Äúnot the one you hoped it would be‚Äù. It feels like a deceptive practice and it would help everyone, including them to be forthcoming and honest, rather than trying to trick someone into swiping right and finding out it‚Äôs not the intended person that you swiped. 

Otherwise, you‚Äôre playing ‚ÄúBumble Roulette‚Äù

I think it‚Äôs a sensible suggestion.

author: Fjgddbh
title: Used to be Great, Now Very Disappointing
review: I used to absolutely love Bumble and recommend it to anyone who was interested in trying online dating. Within the last year everything is behind a paywall. I loved the feature that gave you three back swipes a day because so many times I would accidentally swipe left on someone I was interested but then I was able to correct my mistake. Now for the low price of $8.99 a month you can get those back swipes back. They also set a limit on how many people you can swipe on a day, but have no fear because behind a paywall you can have unlimited swipes. I loved using bumble when I first moved because it gave me opportunities to meet someone while busy in my graduate program. I‚Äôm a broke student so I can‚Äôt justify the cost but Bumble used to be waaaay better before paywalling everything. Bumble tries justifying this by saying they want you to form ‚Äúmeaningful connections‚Äù but at $7.99/week just say you gotta make money.

author: Make it Easy Bumble
title: Holds you hostage when you sign up for premium
review: I wanted to try premium, then went to cancel for now, and the make it impossible. There‚Äôs no contact number, and the only feedback I‚Äôve been sent is to go through iTunes, which I don‚Äôt have. They have no other ways to do it and now I have to wait for an automated system to hopefully send another email in 2-3 business days. DONT SIGN UP FOR PREMIUM UNLESS YOU WANT TO USE IT FOR A LONG TIME AND HAVE A HORRIBLE TIME CANCELLING

author: Mira J Fenix
title: Hadn't used this app in 5 years
review:
And they've become just as corrupt as every other dating app. The first thing you're met with is a subscription dashboard. They really separate themselves in that sense. They make it clear that the sole purpose of the app is to take money. 

But my main problem was the unexplained censorship. I used a photo that was perfectly fine on match, hinge, and coffee meets bagel but not Bumble. They refused to explain why they were taking the photo down when I messaged them and I looked up the guidelines and my photo was perfectly fine. Bumble must have some Puritan standards because that extremism is the only way the photo could be considered inappropriate. I guess my halloween costume as a vampire bunny from the ribcage up was just too raunchy for their Puritan standards. Must gave been the exposed shoulders and uncovered collar bones. That or the moderation system is a really catty insecure person. 

Online dating should make dating so much easier since the person has a chance to tell you about themselves and you can determine compatibility, but instead it's been ruined by greed. It was much better across the board 6 years ago.

author: rantee
title: Elegant UI, unnecessary location usage
review:
This app is pleasant to use but its reliance on location permissions should be optional for two big reasons. Users should not be forced into this privacy-unfriendly design. Requiring *a* location is fine, but not my precise location. Which relates to reason 2 -

The radius-based search is often meaningless and hides many relevant matches - there are many places 20 miles away from my home that I can get to faster than others that are 10 miles away. If I could manually enter or change my zip code, for example, I could find much more geographically-relevant matches.

Finally, the subscriptions are too pricey.

You won‚Äôt show up to people you swipe right on. Matches rarely happen. I get only a couple a month & rarely will the girl even send a message.

Edit: now that I live in NYC (used to live in LA) I get regular matches. Still only a few conversations but I have good success of conversation to date, and have had ~10 first dates in the past 3 months. Still wish the algorithm was better. Having someone ‚Äúin your beeline‚Äù is almost impossible to swipe right on them cause they never show up in my feed.

author: Simanonok
title: Improved from before
review:
The developer had made his own Bumble obsolete on older iPhones, but now has apparently fixed that problem so I‚Äôm back to testing if it‚Äôs really usable. 

Two major problems I see are 

1) the use of meaningless hieroglyphic icons that seem to randomly switch around on every page makes navigation very tedious and difficult; WHEN will developers learn to use text menus that we can just look at to see what they‚Äôre for, instead of having to experiment by clicking on every one to see if they do something useful or are what we‚Äôre looking for?  A single drop down text menu in the upper left corner where menus belong would be a massive improvement in usability, instead of scattering meaningless hieroglyphs randomly around the screen. 

2) poor contrast of light yellow-orangey text on white backgrounds in Setup areas makes certain operations slow and difficult. Not as bad as the use of meaningless icons, but still unnecessary. Suspect the developer isn‚Äôt using naive testers on a variety of devices like he should, but instead is probably developing on a Mac with a high contrast screen where his light-on-light text is discernible and where the use of meaningless hieroglyphics for navigation has long been standard practice‚Äîand the reason that I and many others loathe Apple products.

review:

Or I‚Äôll waste a super swipe because I couldn‚Äôt undo it in time. It‚Äôs really easy to make a mistake from the beeline view where profiles are shown two per row, because you try to swipe the person on the left and it selects the person on the right. (Though if this were fixed, the two per row is nice.) 

My biggest issue ‚Äî my beeline my filters don‚Äôt work at all, so I‚Äôm stuck going thru matches that are way outside of my distance parameters in order to review the people who are local. 

Not worth the cost of premium AT ALL when these feature's don‚Äôt work.

author: GoudaMeunster
title: Algorithm and Filters need improvement
review:
I‚Äôm old enough to know what I want and what I don‚Äôt want, and it‚Äôs painfully obvious that people don‚Äôt read profiles, so why aren‚Äôt the preference settings more robust?
I‚Äôm not talking about the shallow things like height or whatever, but whether my profile gets show to people who live out of town and need a tour guide because they haven‚Äôt heard of Rick Steves, or are looking for a unicorn to throuple with. I am interested in neither of those things, thank you. It seems like it would be highly useful to partition what information you share with others given the Bizz and BFF settings, and to have more control over that ‚ÄîI‚Äôm not going to talk about the same things with each of those groups on a first or second meeting and want to present myself accordingly.

Dating is hard enough and I don‚Äôt feel like this is making my life easier

author: Josh_805
title: Gender settings are nice, but a bit weird.
review: This app is overall okay. I like that they have a lot of options on things you can add to your profile, but their monthly price is really high. $40 for basically one month, and $20 for a week, just so you can see people who have swiped on you or even to just filter things such as height preference. But what really gets me here, is the way they handle gender identity and how they categorize it. I‚Äôm a trans male, who‚Äôs interested in women, and I‚Äôve had no problems in my past with dating women. But if I change my gender identity to ‚Äútrans man‚Äù on this app and set my preference as ‚Äúwomen‚Äù my feed is changed to nothing but other women who are interested in women, or people looking for ‚Äúpoly‚Äù relationships. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm quite what lesbians are looking for bumble? But once I set my gender back to ‚Äúmale‚Äù I‚Äôm brought back to women who are interested in men. So I have no choice but to just put ‚Äúmale‚Äù and then that I‚Äôm ‚Äútrans‚Äù in my bio. So maybe something needs to be changed about that? Why should I feel that I‚Äôm less of a man on this app? I get that you try and pair ‚Äúlgbtq+‚Äù with others in that same category, but make it make sense. If I say I‚Äôm ‚Äústraight‚Äù I should only be seeing what my preference is. If others choose to not like me because I‚Äôm trans, let them make that decision.

review: I‚Äôve been using the app for several years. On this account specifically, over a year. I‚Äôve really had no complaints until now. The other morning I woke up to find myself blocked from the app. I used my phone to log in, so I never received an email, never a text or warning screen or anything, that I was blocked. I had to find out from screen recording my screen to just barely catch a red box of text that says ‚Äú..een blocked‚Äù. I got a better view eventually that said ‚Äúyou have been blocked.‚Äù Nice. Turns out I had a subscription renewal coming up, and guess what? Yup, it renewed. For an account that‚Äôs blocked, they still take your money though! Blocked for no reason, I‚Äôve never broken a guideline or done anything wrong on the app. I don‚Äôt advertise a snap or Instagram, my pictures are of just me, and I‚Äôm respectful to my matches. Not recommending at this moment until this is resolved.

But like bees to honey, the men wouldn‚Äôt be signing up if they didn‚Äôt hear about the women on here. So that means, the women joining in the past 2-3 years has changed. Also,  Lots of guys writing that they‚Äôre in an ENM relationship ‚Äúlooking‚Äù. Truly a dating app can be taken over by this new group of ENM or POLY. It then breeds all other groups and relationship types. Ruining a dating app.

author: acom1993
title: Company became too greedy
review: This app used to be great until they started forcing users to pay for features that used to be free. When the pandemic hit, people needed dating apps in order to meet people, and the company capitalized off of that and took a greedy turn for the worse. You used to get a large number of swipes per day which is now limited to about 25. This smaller number of swipes is sold under the illusion of ‚Äúthoughtful swiping,‚Äù but if the company actually cared about ‚Äúthoughtful swiping‚Äù then they wouldn‚Äôt offer unlimited swiping like they do in their paid version in the first place. They also took away the free back track feature that lets you bring back profiles you accidentally swiped left on, and took away the ability to bring back one expired match every 24 hours. It‚Äôs a shame because they app used to be great but it really fell off. Now the app is just geared towards getting people to pay for the premium version which is way over priced. For shame.

author: delighted.rock
title: Has slipped a lot
review: Been using this app for over 5 years and met some amazing partners through it. By comparison to the other dating apps it was hands the best one. Over the years though it has slowly slipped out of that top spot; the quality of the people on the app has gone down while the costs of their various features has gone up. Now I‚Äôd rank Bumble below Hinge and Tinder in terms of overall experience. I‚Äôm pretty sure this is all because Bumble used to advertise like crazy in the my city (NYC) and had built up a really quality brand that attracted good people. Post Covid that has seem to fall away and thus the quality people have all migrated to other places.

Bumble doesn‚Äôt work well for those in wheelchairs. I get plenty of matches on Hinge & Tinder. I‚Äôm worried that bumble is discriminating the disabled by showing their profiles less or giving them lower scores on the basis of being disabled.

If they made changes Bumble would be solid. I‚Äôm trying to like this app.

author: Pinkie B
title: BFF has gender issues
review:
I'm a female who prefers male friends. I list myself as "genderqueer" because I think it best represents my personality, and because doing so allows me to choose how I want to present. 

Bumble only allows me to show my profile to people who want to match with men OR who want women, but not either or both at once. This is a major flaw in gender representation if ultimately you are forced into the binary box. 

According to this app gender really is just a label, but doesn't have any real effect on your relationships. I think they're massively missing the point. 

Oh, and their prices are outrageous.

Kinda disappointed and not sure if I want to continue using the app because I‚Äôm unsure if my profile will be reaching the right audience

author: WesleyG92
title: Bumble BFF is Homophobic
review:
Bumble BFF inherently recognizes that people need to make friends, new friends. This is especially crucial when for example you move or enter a period of new growth. And BFF inherently recognizes that people sometimes are solely looking for friends where sex can never be an option and harassment is a nonstarter, hence it limits matches only to the same gender. That only works for heterosexual people, and there is no way to change that setting. Cis-identifying queer people have no way of seeking platonic friendships safe from the risk of harassment or sexual pressure. And the utilization of the binary completely removes choice and sense of belonging for trans and non-binary folx for whom harassment and sexual pressure are never off the table anyways.

In short, why is the platonic side of this app geared first and foremost with cis-hets in mind, with virtually no liberty for queer people? Do we not deserve friends of our own choosing? Are we inherently incapable of making lasting and deep friendships with others of different gender identities?? Bumble BFF answers the latter two questions with a resounding YES. Shameful.

author: rwilsonltf
title: Basically a scam
review:
Been paying for the ‚Äúpremium‚Äù subscription for 3 months now and have gotten 1 match. I have a fully filled out profile and spend at least 30 minutes a day  on the app. Not only have I only gotten 1 match where they never even messaged me but I get maybe 1 like every 2 weeks and it‚Äôs always the same person, so probably not a real account. The Super Likes do absolutely nothing from what I can tell which you have to pay extra for. Even though I pay $20 a month (which is ridiculous btw) you have to pay an extra $5 to even be shown on other peoples profiles, and even so your only shown for 30 minutes. I‚Äôve done it once and maybe got 2 likes so it‚Äôs very clear that is the only way for your account to be shown to other people. If you actually want to match and talk to real people on this app be ready to spend $50-$100 a month.

On top of all this it never shows you anyone with similar interests, maybe 1 out of 20 people shown will have similar interests and wants as you. 

These developers clearly don‚Äôt care about matching people up, it‚Äôs purely an app to try and squeeze every last dollar out of you for nothing in return. Spend your money elsewhere and don‚Äôt waste your time with this app.

The good: the interface is user-friendly and looks nice. Prompts are fine, not great.

The bad: my profile identifies me as a woman interested in women; but probably at least 1 in 10 profiles is a heterosexual couple **looking for a third!** which is really fetishy and uncomfortable. First of all, it seems bizarre that bumble isn‚Äôt regulating or tracking whether profiles belong to individuals or couples, and second, if they‚Äôre allowing couples to have profiles, then they should at least also give users the option to filter them out and only see individuals if they so choose.

The whole experience just feels icky to me because I‚Äôm looking for someone to date monogamously, and I don‚Äôt like thinking that these straight men are just reviewing my profile wondering if I‚Äôll be the one to help him fulfill his gross fantasy of a threesome with a lesbian who **maybe he can turn!**

author: Dan Aykroyd Assult
title: Update buggy
review: When I first signed up I didn‚Äôt have any likes at all. Usually you get some just from random scrolling. It‚Äôs not about being attractive it‚Äôs just what happens people swipe right on you late at night. then about two weeks later before I went to bed I had two likes in my queue and then I woke up I had 12. I don‚Äôt know what the algorithm was doing but it was messing around. And now with the update I had six guys in my queue and then they all disappeared and then the next day I had one and the day after that I had four of the guys who were previously in my queue suddenly reappear.And now I‚Äôm back down to two. I‚Äôve had no new likes in the past five days. I think the algorithm is off. And the hive that bumble has me in keeps me stuck.

author: Chris from Jax

What is even the point?

author: mnbvzrhbsghjbdkkmcfjvdjvaegb
title: Money scam!
review: So been on this for years. Had both good and bad but now it‚Äôs become clear it is strictly about money for them. I highly discourage anyone for paying for this app ever. They intentionally throttle your likes once you cancel. I signed up a month and once cancelled the likes in a day went down dramatically. Including one day limiting me to a total of 9! For the entire day. Plus they micromanage how you can use those like. I‚Äôve have them stop likes for hours after only 3 consecutive right swipes but they then say you can upgrade. Absolute worse app. I suggest Hinge if you want that few likes. At least there you can send a message.
